bibl.title: Letter from Luis B. Pogolotti to Philip Showalter Hench, June 20, 1940

div1.p: Pogolotti informs Hench that the photographs have not yet been received. He thanks him for his medical advice.

div1.head: Letter from Luis B. Pogolotti to Philip Showalter Hench, June 20, 1940
div1.p:
I received your letter of June 4th
and see that you wrote to me
another letter before and also
sent me the photographs.

I am very sorry to say-that
I have not received neither one
so far, and I am afraid they
both went lost.

You must not worry about
the money of the blue prints,
as Mr. Moran has paid
every thing.

You have a good “General
Mamayen” in Mr. Moran who
by the way has received from
the Cuban Government a medal
and a title of the “Finlay's Institution”

Thanks for the informations
about asthma, and more thanks
for your kind invitation to the
Clinic.

Mine, is an old trouble,
and although I was born in the
Northernest part of Italy, I don't
think I can stand cold weather
any more, because, if during
the "terrible winter of Cuba
I get my nose “closed” on
both sides and “running”
with asthma, what would
become of me in a cold
State as Minnesota?

I am afraid you would
have to “Ship” me back.

During the summer I
am th OK. but in October my
troubles begin, and then until
March. I have received several
treatments and my big hope is
that some new products will be found
or prepared, because if asthma
is as spread in the World as it
is in Cuba, something must be
done by scientists to find the
cure or more definite releif for it.

The Cuban authorities have not
done anything lately on the
Lazear's Camp. (near the Hospital)
but me we are not surprised
for that, as we are (finishing) in
a violent elections period wich
will end next 14th of July.

With my best regards to
Mrs. Hench. I remain
